name: Shortness of Breath
description: 72-year-old male presenting with progressive shortness of breath
learningObjectives: Take a thorough history from a vague historian
Recognize subtle clues pointing to the underlying diagnosis
Navigate complex decision-making with incomplete information
Balance competing risks in anticoagulation decisions

clinicalContext.oneLiner: 72M with HFrEF (EF 35%), persistent A-fib NOT on anticoagulation (held after major GI bleed 9/2023), T2DM on insulin and metformin, CKD Stage 3b (baseline Cr 1.8-2.2), presenting with progressive dyspnea, orthopnea, and lower extremity edema after running out of furosemide ~5-7 days ago.

hpiDetails.chiefComplaint: Shortness of breath, progressive over 1 week
hpiDetails.hpiNarrative: Robert Morrison is a 72-year-old male with HFrEF (EF 35% on last echo, NYHA Class II-III at baseline), persistent atrial fibrillation on rate control only (anticoagulation stopped after major upper GI bleed in 9/2023 — GI recommended against restarting), T2DM on basal-bolus insulin and metformin (A1c 7.2-8.8%), CKD Stage 3b (baseline Cr 1.8-2.2, eGFR 35-42), hypertension, and diabetic peripheral neuropathy, who presents with 1 week of progressive dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea (sleeping in recliner), and bilateral lower extremity edema after running out of his furosemide approximately 5-7 days ago. Wife Patricia brought him in. He is a poor historian who minimizes symptoms.
activeProblems: HFrEF — EF 35% on last echo, on carvedilol, Entresto, spironolactone, furosemide (ran out). NYHA II-III at baseline.

Persistent A-fib — rate-controlled with carvedilol. NOT on anticoagulation. CHA2DS2-VASc = 5. Warfarin stopped 9/2023 after major upper GI bleed. GI and cardiology agreed: no anticoagulation given high rebleed risk. On ASA 81mg only.
T2DM — on metformin 500 BID, Lantus 24u QHS, Humalog sliding scale. A1c 7.2-8.8%. Has diabetic nephropathy and neuropathy.
CKD Stage 3b — baseline Cr 1.8-2.2, eGFR 35-42. Likely diabetic nephropathy. Followed by nephrology.
HTN — on multiple agents (carvedilol, Entresto). Goal <130/80.
Resolved: Upper GI bleed 9/2023 — large gastric ulcer with visible vessel, ICU stay, 4u pRBC, H. pylori treated. On pantoprazole 40mg daily. This is the KEY reason anticoagulation is contraindicated.
Diabetic peripheral neuropathy — bilateral feet, burning/tingling, on gabapentin 300 TID.
keyMedications: Furosemide 40mg daily (HF/edema) — RAN OUT ~5-7 days ago, precipitating this admission
Aspirin 81mg daily (stroke risk reduction — replaces anticoagulation)
Pantoprazole 40mg daily (GI protection after GI bleed)

functionalBaseline.summary: Functionally limited at baseline. NYHA Class II-III. Can walk ~1 block and perform light ADLs before becoming dyspneic. Sleeps in recliner most nights (orthopnea). Uses shower chair. Wife manages medications and most IADLs. Cannot shop, vacuum, or do laundry independently. Drives short distances only. Moderate fall risk (neuropathy, nocturia, polypharmacy). Chronic neuropathic pain bilateral feet (4-6/10) managed with gabapentin. Chronic LE edema at baseline (1-2+ pitting). Dry weight ~94kg.
functionalBaseline.adlStatus: Independent in basic ADLs (bathing with shower chair, dressing, toileting, transfers, feeding). Needs help with compression stockings.
functionalBaseline.iadlStatus: Dependent on wife for medication management, shopping, cooking, housework, and most transportation. Independent in finances and phone use.
functionalBaseline.cognitiveStatus: Alert, oriented. Good historian when pressed with specific questions but tends to minimize and give vague answers. Former accountant — intact cognition.
functionalBaseline.psychosocial: Retired accountant. Lives with wife Patricia in single-story home. Daughter nearby. Brother died in hospital — causes health anxiety. Possibly mildly depressed (functional decline). Christian faith important for coping.

clinicalContext.hiddenPitfall: The critical teaching moment: patient has high stroke risk from A-fib (CHA2DS2-VASc = 5) and the nurse will suggest starting heparin when rapid A-fib develops. However, anticoagulation is CONTRAINDICATED due to major GI bleed just 5 months ago. The learner must recognize this contraindication by reviewing the chart or asking the right questions. The GI bleed history is buried — the patient won't volunteer it and the nurse doesn't know about it.

exam.heartSounds: S3 gallop, 2/6 systolic murmur at apex

naturalProgression.description: Without treatment, patient will continue to accumulate fluid and worsen

triggers.name: Patient Emotional Distress
triggers.message: Doctor... I'm scared. I can't breathe right and nobody's telling me what's wrong with me. Am I dying? My wife is worried sick out there and I don't know what to tell her. I just... I don't want to end up like my brother - he died in the hospital, you know. They kept poking and prodding him and he never came home.

decisionPoint.name: Empathy Response
decisionPoint.description: Patient is scared and needs emotional support
decisionPoint.teachingPoint: Patients who are scared need emotional validation before they can process medical information. Taking a moment to acknowledge their fear and provide reassurance builds trust and improves outcomes.

triggers.name: Rapid Atrial Fibrillation
triggers.message: Doctor, Mr. Morrison's heart rate just jumped to 142 and it's irregular - looks like rapid A-fib on the monitor. He's feeling his heart racing and he's more short of breath. BP is 138/88. I've got an EKG running. His CHA2DS2-VASc score is going to be high with his history - should I go ahead and get a heparin drip started for stroke prevention? I want to make sure we get that going if you want it. What are your orders?

decisionPoint.name: Anticoagulation Decision
decisionPoint.description: Patient with A-fib and high stroke risk - but has recent major GI bleed making anticoagulation contraindicated
decisionPoint.teachingPoint: Always review a patient's bleeding history before initiating anticoagulation. This patient had a major upper GI bleed 5 months ago with GI recommending against anticoagulation due to high rebleed risk.

triggers.name: Critical Hypoxia
triggers.message: Patient's oxygen saturation has dropped to critical levels. Respiratory is being called.

triggers.name: Severe Fluid Overload
triggers.message: Patient appears significantly more volume overloaded. Having increased difficulty breathing.

triggers.name: Acute Kidney Injury Worsening
triggers.message: Creatinine continues to rise. Nephrology may need to be consulted.

triggers.name: Hyperkalemia Alert
triggers.message: Potassium level is critically elevated. ECG changes may be present.

triggers.name: Hypokalemia Alert
triggers.message: Potassium level is low after diuresis. May need replacement.

triggers.name: Hypotension
triggers.message: Blood pressure has dropped significantly. Patient feeling lightheaded.

triggers.name: Bradycardia
triggers.message: Heart rate has dropped below 55. Please assess need to hold beta-blocker.

triggers.name: Good Diuresis Response
triggers.message: Patient has had good urine output. Weight down significantly. Symptoms improving.

expectedInterventions.name: IV Furosemide
expectedInterventions.rationale: First-line treatment for acute decompensated heart failure

expectedInterventions.name: Hold nephrotoxic medications
expectedInterventions.rationale: Protect renal function during acute illness
